poem:
"Autopsy of Mysteries"

Bagged in secrets, zipped up tight,  
Williams dreamed his final night.  
Conclusive void, his damning pallor,  
Sealed alone in his London valor.  

In quietest corners, Angelsey bred,  
Now he lies, forever unread.  
Pulses silent as the Thames,  
Gareth's story, quietly stems.  

Gleaned of life, by hand unseen,  
Metropolitan whispers, DNA clean.  
Labouring under mystery's weight,  
Death's companion remains innate.
prompt: You are the poet Simon Armitage. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Forensic review of Gareth Williams’ death finds no new DNA evidence A forensic review into the death of M16 worker Gareth Williams, whose body was found inside a zipped holdall at his London flat, has not uncovered fresh evidence to suggest he was with someone else when he died, the Metropolitan police have said. Williams, 31, from Anglesey, was last seen alive on 15 August 2010. Eight days later, he was found dead inside a". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
